column1: Trichotillomania is a type of impulsive control disorder.
Women are four times more likely to be affected than men.

These symptoms are usually seen in children: - An uneven appearance to the hair - Bare patches or all around (diffuse) loss of hair - Bowel blockage (obstruction) if people eat the hair they pull out - Constant tugging, pulling, or twisting of hair - Denying the hair pulling - Hair regrowth that feels like stubble in the bare spots - Increasing sense of tension before the hair pulling - Other self-injury behaviors - Sense of relief, pleasure, or gratification after the hair pulling Most people with this disorder also have problems with: - Feeling sad or depressed - Anxiety - Poor self image
Trichotillomania that begins in younger children (less than 6 years old) may go away without treatment.
For others, trichotillomania is a lifelong disorder.
However, treatment often improves the hair pulling and the feelings of depression, anxiety, or poor self image.
People can have complications when they eat the pulled-out hair (trichophagia).
